F1.immediateAction: Check system pressure on gauge - should be 1.0-1.5 bar when cold

F2.immediateAction: Check gas supply is on, boiler will attempt to re-ignite automatically
possibleCauses: Flame sensing electrode dirty or faulty

technicalDetails.triggerCondition: Flame signal lost during burner operation
technicalDetails.flameElectrodePosition: Must be in flame path, 3-5mm from burner

F3.immediateAction: Check flue terminal outside for blockages

F4.immediateAction: Check thermistor is properly clipped to flow pipe
possibleCauses: Thermistor not making contact with pipe

L2.immediateAction: Press reset button. If fault persists, call engineer

technicalDetails.ignitionSequence: Fan pre-purge → Spark → Gas valve opens → Flame detect

F28.description: Ignition Fault - No Gas Supply Detected
F28.immediateAction: Check gas meter and isolation valve are open
possibleCauses: Gas supply turned off at meter

technicalDetails.detectionMethod: No flame signal within ignition window

F61.immediateAction: Reset boiler - if persists, requires engineer

technicalDetails.faultDetection: PCB self-diagnostic detects gas valve control circuit abnormality
technicalDetails.gasValveDriver: Triac or relay control on PCB
technicalDetails.diagnosticLED: Red LED flashing pattern indicates fault type
technicalDetails.resetProcedure: Power off 30 seconds, power on, check fault persists

F73.immediateAction: Check pressure sensor wiring and connections

pressure-low.name: Low System Pressure Diagnostic
toolsRequired: Footpump with pressure gauge (for expansion vessel)
safetyWarnings: System may be pressurized - release pressure slowly
Hot water risk - allow system to cool before draining
Gas Safe registration required for gas-side work

steps.title: Visual Pressure Check
steps.instruction: Read the system pressure gauge on the boiler front panel
steps.actualProblem: Reading below 0.5 bar triggers F1 fault
steps.action: If below 0.5 bar, continue to step 2. If above 1.5 bar, different fault.

steps.title: Visual Leak Inspection - Boiler Area
steps.instruction: Open boiler casing and inspect inside for water
checkPoints: Under pump - common leak point from pump shaft seal
Automatic air vent (AAV) - should be dry, not weeping
Pressure relief valve pipe (usually copper, exits outside)
steps.expectedResult: All areas should be completely dry
steps.action: If wet, identify source and proceed to leak repair

steps.title: External Pressure Relief Valve Check
steps.instruction: Go outside and locate PRV discharge pipe (usually 15mm copper)
checkPoints: Pipe should terminate outside (cannot be hidden)
Check for water dripping or staining
Check ground below pipe for damp patches
steps.expectedResult: PRV discharge pipe should be bone dry

technicalInfo.commonCause: Expansion vessel failure causes pressure rise, PRV opens, then pressure drops when cold

steps.action: If PRV has been discharging, proceed to expansion vessel test (step 8)

steps.title: Radiator Valve Inspection
steps.instruction: Check ALL radiators in property for leaks
checkPoints: TRV bodies - check compression nuts are tight
Lockshield valve bodies - check for weeping
Bleed valves - should be closed tight
Radiator to valve unions - look for green marks (sign of historic leak)
steps.tool: Tissue paper - hold against joints to detect minor weeps
steps.action: Tighten any loose connections using adjustable spanner

steps.title: System Repressurise Test
steps.instruction: Top up system pressure using filling loop
procedure: Locate filling loop under boiler (two valves, usually blue or black)
When gauge reaches 1.2 bar, close both valves
Check both valves are fully closed - try turning clockwise
steps.expectedResult: Pressure should be 1.2 bar and stable
steps.criticalCheck: If pressure immediately drops, ACTIVE LEAK present - do not operate boiler
steps.action: Wait 30 minutes and re-check pressure. If stable, proceed to step 6. If dropping, find leak source.

steps.title: Pressure Stability Test
procedure: Record pressure when cold next day

expectedResults.cold_next_day: Should be same as initial cold pressure ±0.1 bar

diagnosis.pressureDropsWhenCold: Leak in system - continue leak detection
diagnosis.pressureRisesExcessively: Expansion vessel fault - proceed to step 8

steps.title: Leak Detection - Advanced
steps.instruction: If leak not visible, use detection methods

methods.procedure: Pressurize system to 2.5 bar and monitor for drops
Check walls, floors, ceilings near pipes
Scan for cold spots indicating leaking water
Add fluorescent dye to system, scan with UV light after 24hrs

commonHiddenLeaks: Radiators on upper floors with leak dripping to ceiling

steps.title: Expansion Vessel Test
steps.background: Vessel absorbs expansion of water as it heats. Contains air bladder at ~1 bar. If bladder fails, no expansion capacity = high pressure = PRV opens = pressure loss when cold.
procedure: Drain boiler to 0 bar using drain valve
Locate vessel Schrader valve (car tyre type) - usually red cap
FAULT: Water comes out = burst diaphragm

testWithPressureGauge.procedure: With system at 0 bar, measure vessel pressure
testWithPressureGauge.zeroReading: Vessel has lost charge or diaphragm failed

action.lowAirPressure: Re-pressurize to 1.0 bar and retest system
action.correctPressure: Vessel OK - leak must be elsewhere

steps.title: Automatic Air Vent (AAV) Check
steps.location: Top of boiler or high point in system
checkProcedure: Inspect AAV body for water marks
Check thread for white calcium deposits (dried water)

steps.title: Filling Loop Isolation Valve Check
steps.instruction: Ensure filling loop valves are fully closed
steps.commonProblem: Valves can pass (leak) even when closed
testProcedure: Both filling loop valves should be quarter-turn type or screw-down
Turn both valves clockwise as far as they go
If pressure rises when valves supposedly closed = passing valve
Listen for water trickling sound near filling loop
steps.action: Replace filling loop if valves passing
steps.preventativeMaintenance: Disconnect flexible filling loop when not in use

diagnosticDecisionTree.pRVDripping: Test expansion vessel - if failed, replace
diagnosticDecisionTree.nOVisibleLeak_PressureDropsSlow: Use advanced leak detection or accept minor loss and top-up monthly
diagnosticDecisionTree.nOLeak_PressureStable: Fault was one-time pressure loss - monitor for recurrence

steps: Set multimeter to Ohms (Ω) range - use 20kΩ or 200kΩ range
Place multimeter probes on thermistor terminals

interpretation.openCircuit: Multimeter shows OL or ∞ = thermistor failed open

thermistor-resistance-test.temperatureTest: Warm thermistor in hand - resistance should DROP steadily (NTC type)
thermistor-resistance-test.replacementRequired: If reads OL, 0Ω, or doesn't change with temperature

gas-pressure-test.safety: Gas Safe registration REQUIRED. Gas testing is regulated work.
gas-pressure-test.legalRequirement: Only Gas Safe registered engineers can perform gas tests
procedure: Connect manometer to gas valve test point (remove screw, attach tube)
Turn boiler on - call for heat

naturalGas_Readings.lowPressureCause: Network supply issue - contact gas supplier

lPG_Readings.workingPressure: Varies by boiler model - check manual

gas-pressure-test.criticalSafety: If pressure <18 mbar, DO NOT use boiler - gas supplier fault

voltageTest.faultIfNoVoltage: PCB pump output fault or wiring issue

resistanceTest.openCircuit: OL reading = burned out motor winding

commonFaults: Seized shaft (bearings worn) - manual release stuck
Motor winding failure - resistance out of range
